newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul shares end lower on consolidation.
newsitem.headline: Seoul shares end lower on consolidation.

text.p: Stocks closed lower on Monday as blue chips came under profit-taking after a rally last week and buying focused on a handful of theme-backed small shares, brokers said.
"It looks like a technical correction. Most blue chips, seen overbought, faced profit-taking," said Lee Young-won, a broker at Daewoo Securities.
The composite index closed 5.73 points lower at 773.51.
"Consolidation will continue in early Tuesday trading. But we may see stocks rebounding towards the close, albeit slightly," said Choo Hee-yup of Dongwon Securities.
The stock index options trading opened on Monday for the first time, in slow mood.
The underlying contract for the At-The-Money (ATM) options, the spot month, began at 82.5. It would be set at 80.0 on Tuesday. The KOSPI 200 closed at 81.10, down from 81.94 on Saturday.
The Out-Of-The-Money (OTM) call options for the spot month totalled 1,332 contracts.
Brokers said overall sentiment was backed by improving economic fundamentals.
The central bank said on Monday it lowered its forecast for this year's current account deficit to $17 billion from $18 billion.
Last week, South Korea said its trade account turned into a surplus in June, the first monthly trade surplus in 30 months.
Samsung Electronics dropped 1,500 won to 70,500, and POSCO 200 won to 65,300.
Shares in Hanil Leasing went limit-up on a local news report U.S. General Electric Capital Corp was trying to buy a 31.5 percent stake in the South Korean company, brokers said.
Hanil rose 620 won to its limit of 8,420.
Trading volume totalled 38.44 million shares, compared with 29.89 million for Saturday's half-day trading.
Losers outpaced gainers 428 to 338 with 129 unchanged.
